awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Protoflight Design and Validation of Molten Regolith Electrolysis Facility For Lunar In-Situ Resource Utilization
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to open the path for resource extraction on the Moon, creating an in-space manufacturing industry, allowing for a permanent presence on the Moon, and expanding the ability to explore the inner planets of the solar system. The technology may result in the ability of humans to operate and live in space: building state-of-the-art research infrastructure, exploring the solar system, creating a space economy independent of Earth, and moving terrestrial manufacturing and power generation into space.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project may provide new insights into electrorefining metal oxide feedstocks, specifically lunar regolith simulants, through high-temperature electrolysis to yield oxygen and metals. Additionally, the proposed technology will address anode stability and advance studies in novel platinum group metal anodes. The team will use multi-physics modeling for high-temperature electrolysis and for modeling low gravity and lunar vacuum environments. The project may result in the ability to extract oxygen and raw metals from lunar regoliths advancing research in space resource extraction efforts. This advancement in knowledge may aide in the research and development efforts in the fields of materials science, inorganic chemistry, and metallurgy which could result in the carbon-free production of steel and other metals on Earth, new anode materials for high-temperature electrolysis, new electrochemical processes for electrorefining raw feedstocks, and the ability to source oxygen and metals from the Moon and other planetary bodies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Lunar Resources, Inc (LUNAR) is developing molten regolith electrolysis (MRE) as an in-situ resource utilization (ISRU) technology to enable long-term, sustainable human activity on the moon. There are several desirable advantages of MRE for ISRU applications, chief among them is that it requires only electricity  as an input to produce metals and oxygen from lunar soil.

This Phase II project built on the modelling and laboratory-scale experiments done in Phase I to develop and test full-scale MRE rectors. Reactors of two different sizes were built based on multiphysics simulations of the MRE process: one sized for initial lunar demonstration and the other, larger one, intended for commercial throughput. In addition, a complete process control and data acquisition system was developed.  Further a novel heaters capable of melting regolith in preparation for the electrolysis process was developed, along with systems for cooling and purifying the extracted oxygen, tapping the produced metal and slag, and for reloading regolith into the reactor.

The technology developed as part of this Phase II work is now ready to advance to the lunar demonstration stage. LUNAR is continuing to refine the MRE process with the goals of demonstrating on the Moon metals extraction and upstream processing of the metals for lunar infrastructure development. The developments and lessons learned in this project will have significant implications for both the burgeoning space economy and the ongoing effort to decarbonize industry here on Earth and build a more sustainable future for all.


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: Alex Ignatiev
